channel.title: Back at it again
channel.description:
Okay I haven't modeled or posted in over 2 years and I decided to try it again just for fun..
Obviously I am open to all criticism and/or helpful hints
the top model is from 2 years ago and the bottom the new one. I just used the same materials for both
[img]https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/Bl1qQZBzmckGuR5n2uSJxPn3KUMpiJyIUmCqc1TXtIc=w799-h599-no[/img]
WireFrame:
[img]https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-UA2z60HY8-WBT5GxT3e5EcKFvqjxy93uyoeLalaWfI=w1169-h599-no[/img]

item.title: Back at it again
item.dc:creator: @MeeE59 MeeE59
item.description:
@MeeE59 wrote:

[quote=“amy_webb, post:4, topic:552598”]Take a shape, for example a sphere, and use the alpha in material to make it see through. Copy the sphere and make it smaller so that you get a layered texture which makes it look like its fading. An example would be:

[spoiler]

Boogie_bow_detail.png1021×1053
[/spoiler]

If you look at the bow strings on that, you can see the effects.

[spoiler]

[/spoiler]

In those pictures, you can see how i used the obj layers to make it look faded while they all have the same material. The last one is the end result of it.

Then you take this, apply it to the middle of the sword or around the areas which aren’t joined and it appears magical.

That being said, you can also copy the whole sword wireframe and apply it the same way to make it all glow, or just the blade even. Whichever you think is better. :)[/quote]

Unfortunately this only works to an extent on newer revisions. Particles and stuff don’t show through the opacity, it’s actually kinda weird.

Read full topic

item.title: Back at it again
item.dc:creator: @shawn_Allbritton shawn Allbritton
item.description:
@shawn_Allbritton wrote:

[quote=“amy_webb, post:4, topic:552598”]Take a shape, for example a sphere, and use the alpha in material to make it see through. Copy the sphere and make it smaller so that you get a layered texture which makes it look like its fading. An example would be:

[spoiler]

Boogie_bow_detail.png1021×1053
[/spoiler]

If you look at the bow strings on that, you can see the effects.

[spoiler]

[/spoiler]

In those pictures, you can see how i used the obj layers to make it look faded while they all have the same material. The last one is the end result of it.

Then you take this, apply it to the middle of the sword or around the areas which aren’t joined and it appears magical.

That being said, you can also copy the whole sword wireframe and apply it the same way to make it all glow, or just the blade even. Whichever you think is better. :)[/quote]

Didn’t know this was even a thing, that’s kickass! Might have to try that on a model or two.

@allinall Nice model man, keep up the good work!

Read full topic

item.title: Back at it again
item.dc:creator: @amy_webb1 amy_webb
item.description:
@amy_webb1 wrote:

Take a shape, for example a sphere, and use the alpha in material to make it see through. Copy the sphere and make it smaller so that you get a layered texture which makes it look like its fading. An example would be:

[spoiler]

Boogie_bow_detail.png1021×1053
[/spoiler]

If you look at the bow strings on that, you can see the effects.

[spoiler]

[/spoiler]

In those pictures, you can see how i used the obj layers to make it look faded while they all have the same material. The last one is the end result of it.

Then you take this, apply it to the middle of the sword or around the areas which aren’t joined and it appears magical.

That being said, you can also copy the whole sword wireframe and apply it the same way to make it all glow, or just the blade even. Whichever you think is better.

Read full topic

item.title: Back at it again
item.dc:creator: @allinall allinall
item.description:
@allinall wrote:

amy_webb:

Maybe try messing around with some layered effects, make it look more magical.

Thank you for the response. What exactly do you mean by this?

Read full topic
